abstract_summ: Transplant Programs reduced their outpatient activity both in terms of pre‐transplant evaluation (68% of the centers) and transplant recipient follow‐up (100%); a reduction in transplant activity was observed in the first two weeks of March only in the north‐central macro area (23 LTs vs 39 in 2018 and 60 in 2019); overall, SARS‐CoV‐2 infection was registered for 24 liver transplant recipients and 37 health care providers in liver transplant units.Here we report the results of a national survey on kidney transplantation activity in February and March 2020, and the results of a three-round Delphi consensus promoted by four scientific societies: the Italian Society of Organ Transplantation, the Italian Society of Nephrology, the Italian Society of Anesthesia and Intensive Care, and the Italian Group on Antimicrobial Stewardship.Lombardy has been the most affected region in Italy: the current mortality rate of COVID‐19 patients is 18.3% (10 022 deaths; April 10th) with hospitals in Lombardy having to expand the total number of ICU beds from 724 to 1381 to accommodate infected patients.The survey revealed that, starting from March 2020, there was a decline in kidney transplantation activity in Italy, especially for living-related transplants.The Italian Society for Organ Transplantation (SITO) and the Board of Liver Transplant Program Directors issued a survey to assess the initial impact of this pandemic event on the routine activity of 22 Italian Liver Transplant Programs.
